coredata.dc:title: A wide-temperature superior ionic conductive polymer electrolyte for lithium metal battery

Guo, Xianwei
Wang, Zichun
Wang, Boya
He, Shiman
O'Dell, Luke A.

Chen, Liquan
coredata.dc:description: Polymer electrolytes are one of promising candidates that can meet the demands of high safety and stability of high-energy lithium metal batteries. However, the practical applications of polymer electrolytes are usually limited by the low ionic conductivity, narrow electrochemical window and highly interfacial resistance. Here we designed a poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) polymer electrolyte for polymer lithium metal battery by in-situ polymerization method. The new polymer electrolyte provides superior ionic conductivity with 2.1 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C, wide electrochemical window up to 4.5 V (vs. Li+/Li) and excellent interfacial compatibility to electrodes. The ions transports are mainly achieved from the coupling/decoupling between Li ions and oxygen atoms in CO groups, partially from the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in C–O groups, and probably moving/exchange of Li+ between CO and C–O groups in the process of segmental motions in high and low molecular polymers of polymer electrolyte. The lithium metal batteries with LiFePO4 cathode can deliver a high discharge capacity of ~165 mA h g−1 at 25 °C, and even ~104 mA h g−1 at −15 °C with current density of 0.1C. Therefore, the novel polymer electrolyte designed in this study is a promising candidate for high performances polymer lithium metal batteries.

The insert is the photograph of flexible PE film with tunable size.

a, The temperature dependency of ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE. b, The comparisons of ionic conductivities among this PVEC-PE and the other polymer electrolytes. c, LSV profile of the PVEC-PE (the insert is the CV curves of PEVC-PE at scan rate of 1 mV s−1 from −0.5–1.6 V). d, The chronoamperometry profile of Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetric battery under a polarization potential of 10 mV, and the EIS before and after the polarization (insert). e, The TG curves of VEC and PVEC-PE.

a, The dependency of ionic conductivity on mass fraction of AIBN catalyst in PEVC-PE. b, GPC test results of PEVC-PE with different AIBN catalyst. c, The structural schematic diagram of PVEC-PE with long-chain and short-chain molecular. d, The atomic valence state of C and O atoms in PVEC-PE. e-f, 7Li and 6Li NMR spectra of PVEC-PE after different cycle time in Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetric battery. g, Schematic diagram of coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in CO and C–O groups and transport path in PVEC-PE.

The cross-sectional SEM image with interface of the Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetric battery that prepared by a, in-situ and b, ex-situ method. c, The potential profiles of repeated Li plating/striping in Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetric battery by in-situ and ex-situ method with current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 over 600 h at 25 °C. The inserts are the selected potential profiles for different time. d, EIS of the Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetric battery fabricated by in-situ and ex-situ method. e, The comparisons of mass ratio of different elements in the cathodes after removing the PE film from LFP/PVEC-PE/Li battery that prepared by in-situ and ex-situ method. The insets are the SEM images of the surfaces of cathodes.

The comparisons of electrochemical performances of LFP/PVEC-PE/Li batteries that prepared by in-situ and ex-situ method with a, typical charge-discharge curves at current density of 0.1C, b, cycling stabilities at current density of 1C, and c, rate performances. d, The comparisons of charge-discharge curves of LFP/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery under different temperature at current density of 0.1C. e, The typical charge-discharge curves at current density of 0.1 C, and f, the cycling stability at current density of 0.5 C of NCA/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li batteries. g, The schematic diagram of the fabrication of soft package solid polymer LMB, and the optical photographs for the soft package LiFePO4/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery that light up the logo at the normal, wrinkled, cutting, and bending states.

head.ce:title: A wide-temperature superior ionic conductive polymer electrolyte for lithium metal battery

ce:footnote.ce:note-para: These authors contributed equally to this work.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polymer electrolytes are one of promising candidates that can meet the demands of high safety and stability of high-energy lithium metal batteries. However, the practical applications of polymer electrolytes are usually limited by the low ionic conductivity, narrow electrochemical window and highly interfacial resistance. Here we designed a poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) polymer electrolyte for polymer lithium metal battery by in-situ polymerization method. The new polymer electrolyte provides superior ionic conductivity with 2.1 × 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C, wide electrochemical window up to 4.5 V (vs. Li+/Li) and excellent interfacial compatibility to electrodes. The ions transports are mainly achieved from the coupling/decoupling between Li ions and oxygen atoms in CO groups, partially from the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in C–O groups, and probably moving/exchange of Li+ between CO and C–O groups in the process of segmental motions in high and low molecular polymers of polymer electrolyte. The lithium metal batteries with LiFePO4 cathode can deliver a high discharge capacity of ~165 mA h g−1 at 25 °C, and even ~104 mA h g−1 at −15 °C with current density of 0.1C. Therefore, the novel polymer electrolyte designed in this study is a promising candidate for high performances polymer lithium metal batteries.

The practical applications of polymer electrolytes for high-energy lithium metal batteries are still hindered by low ionic conductivity and high interfacial resistance. Here, we proposed a novel poly (vinyl ethylene carbonate) polymer electrolyte for polymer lithium metal battery by in-situ polymerization method. The new polymer electrolyte provides superior ionic conductivity and excellent interfacial compatibility to electrodes. This work provides new design polymer electrolyte is the promising candidates for the practical application of polymer LMBs and could be applied for the flexible electrical devices with high energy density.
Image 1

The superior ionic conductive poly (vinyl ethylene carbonate) polymer electrolyte with wide temperature and electrochemical window has been developed for polymer lithium metal batteries. The excellent interfacial compatibility between electrode and polymer electrolyte that achieved via in-situ polymerization process evidently reduces interfacial resistance toward polymer lithium metal batteries with improved electrochemical performances. This study has important implications in developing highly ionic conductive and stable polymer electrolyte for high-performance polymer lithium metal batteries.

ce:section.ce:para: The increasing demands of powering for the portable electronic devices and electric vehicles are urgent to develop the rechargeable lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with high energy density, long cycle life and good security [1–5]. Lithium metal batteries (LMBs) have attracted great attentions because of the high energy density that originated from the high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mA h g−1) and lowest redox potential (−3.04 V) [6–9]. However, the practical applications of LMBs are still prevented by safety issues in liquid organic electrolytes, which caused by the uncontrollable growth of Li dendrites during the repeated stripping/plating and eventually penetrate through the separators [10–14]. Therefore, several approaches including additives, porous host and surface coating have been applied for the Li metal protection in the liquid electrolytes based LMBs [15–18]. However, the instability of the liquid electrolyte has not fundamentally resolved. On the contrary, the solid electrolytes are considered as the promising candidate to improve the safety of LMBs. Within various solid electrolytes, the inorganic solid electrolytes have high sensitivity to oxygen/moisture, brittleness and poor interfacial compatibility with electrodes, which are not suitable for LMBs [19–24]. In contrast, the polymer electrolytes (PEs) with favorable plasticity can increase the interfacial compatibility to the electrodes against the Li dendrite, which are beneficial for the high-performance LMBs with good safety and high cycling stability [25–29].

It's well known that poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO) based PE has been widely studied for the past decades. However, the relatively low ionic conductivity, narrow electrochemical stability window and poor interface compatibility to the electrode, have seriously hampered the practical applications in LMBs [30–34]. Thus, several strategies have been used to reduce the crystallinity of PEO by co-blending/-polymerization, cross-linking, and interpenetrating by inorganic fillers, in order to increase the ionic conductivity and electrochemical stability window [35–38]. Meanwhile, some other polymers, including poly-1,3-dioxolane (poly-DOL), poly(ethyl α-cyanoacrylate) (PEVA), and poly(vinyl carbonate) (PVCA), and so on, have been developed [39–44]. However, the ionic conductivities of most the reported polymers are still cannot arrive to 1.0 × 10−3 S cm−1 at room temperature (25 °C), which are not sufficient for the preferable electrochemical performances of LMBs. So far, only the poly-DOL PE has the ionic conductivity at the level of 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C. Although the ionic conductivities of plastic crystal, such as succinonitrile (SN) and glutaronitrile (GN) [45–49], and gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), including PETEA and PECA [50], can be up to 10−3 S cm−1 at 25 °C, both of SN and GPE are not the PE and still suffered by their instabilities, which has still severely restricted their further applications for LMBs.

It has been proved that the poly-carbonate based PEs with CO bonds can offer the ions transports pathways and be beneficial for improving the ionic conductivity [27,40]. However, the application these PEs are still suffered by the low ionic conductivity at 25 °C. Specially, the Vinyl ethylene carbonate (VEC) with a unique framework containing CC in the ethylene and CO bonds in the five-membered ring, can be polymerized by the functional groups of CC bonds, and meanwhile, the weaker complexation between CO and Li+ that can facilitate ions transports for high ionic conductivity, which demonstrates the promising application as PE for LMBs [51]. Thus, in this work, a poly(vinyl ethylene carbonate) (PVEC) based PE has been developed via a polymerization process by incorporating the VEC liquid monomer as precursor with the Li salt. The PVEC-PE has a superior ionic conductivity of 2.1 × 10−3 S cm−1 (2.1 mS cm−1) at 25 °C and 0.4 mS cm−1 at −15 °C, stable electrochemical window up to 4.5 V (vs. Li+/Li), and good thermal stability. It has been revealed that the high molecular polymer in PVEC-PE has played as the backbone for the ions migrations, and enhancing the mechanical strength and thermal stability greatly, while the low molecular polymer that filled in the space between high molecular polymer can also improve the ionic conductivity and interfacial compatibility with electrodes. In detail, the superior ionic conductivity is mainly originated from the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in CO groups, partially from the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in C–O groups, and probably moving/exchange of Li+ between CO and C–O groups in the process of segmental motion of PVEC-PE. Furthermore, an integrated electrode with excellent interfacial compatibility between PVEC-PE and cathode or Li metal anode has been successfully achieved via in-situ polymerization, which is beneficial for reducing the interfacial resistance and improving the electrochemical performances. More importantly, the in-situ synthesis method can complete the fabrication of PEs and the formation of polymer LMBs in one step, which can provide an excellent contact and good adhesion between electrolyte and electrodes, and can simplify the assembly process of solid-state batteries. As a result, with LiFePO4 cathode and Li metal anode, the PVEC-PE based LMBs assembled by the in-situ polymerization process deliver high discharge capacity of ~165 mA h g−1 at 0.1C, and good cycling stabilities with specific capacities of ~139 mA h g−1 at 1C and ~118 mA h g−1 at 3C over 100 cycles respectively. Even with the high potential LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode, the LMBs also exhibit excellent electrochemical performances with the specific capacity of ~190 mA h g−1 at 0.1C and keep ~105 mA h g−1 for 200 cycles at 1C. Therefore, the novel PVEC-PE designed in this study is a promising candidate for the practical applications of high performances polymer LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fabrication of polymer electrolyte and polymer battery
ce:section.ce:para: The flexible PVEC-PE with tunable size was fabricated by the solution-casting method. Firstly, liquid VEC monomer (2 g) and LiTFSI (0.5 g) were added into the glass bottle under stirring to form a homogeneous solution in glove box. Subsequently, the 2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN) as the catalyst was added into the solution and stirred for 3 h. Then the homogeneous solution was poured into the Whatman® filter (100% borosilicate glass fiber) on the PTFE plate, followed by the polymerization in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h (marked as ex-situ PVEC-PE). For the PVEC-PE film that used for characterizations and battery test (marked as in-situ PVEC-PE), it has been prepared by the similar polymerization process in the cion cell, and been obtained after disassembling. For the consistency that in the ex-situ polymerization process, the glass fiber membrane was used, which can also enhance the mechanical strength of the PE, and may be beneficial for restraining the Li dendrite growth and enhancing the safety of the battery.

For the fabrication of polymer battery based on PVEC-PE, the convertional method by combing the electrode film and the obtained ex-situ PVEC-PE film, which can be denoted as Li/ex-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery, or LiFePO4/ex-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery. On the contrary, the LiFePO4/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery that fabricated via in-situ polymerization process, which can be described as follows. Typically, LiTFSI (0.5 g) and AIBN were dissolved in liquid VEC monomer (2 g) without any other solvent. Then, the complex was stirring to form a homogeneous solution in glove box. Subsequently, the solution with 30 mL was injected into Whatman® filter in coin-type battery (CR2032), which was adopted as support for polymer electrolyte and separator between cathode and anode to prevent the internal short circuit of the battery before the polymerization of polymer electrolyte. After that, the battery was assembled and transferred to a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h to make the complete polymerization of PVEC-PE.

The Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR) was carried out using a Nexus 870 FTIR spectrometer with the ATR instrument to distinguish the structures of liquid VEC monomer and PVEC-PE. The crystal structure of the PVEC-PE was characterized via XRD with a range of 10°–80°. The morphology and thickness of the SPE was characterized by a field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi S-4800). TG (Perkin Elmer) was carried out to measure the thermal property of the PVEC-PE from 25 to 600 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under nitrogen atmosphere. GPC measurements were performed by dissolving the synthesized PVEC-PE in Trichloromethane and eluting the solutions in a Waters ambient temperature GPC equipped with triple detection capability for absolute polymer molecular weight determination. Solid-state Nuclear Nagnetic Resonance (NMR) investigation, 6Li, 7Li and 13C MAS NMR experiments were carried out on a Bruker Avance III 500 MHz (11.7 T) spectrometer at resonance frequencies of 73.6, 194.4 and 125.7 MHz. Prior to the measurements, the samples were finely ground and packed into 2.5 mm zirconia rotors. The rotors were spun at a MAS rate of 25 kHz in a 2.5 mm HX MAS NMR probe. Spectra were recorded after single-pulse excitation with repetition times of 5, 1 and 1 s for studying 6Li, 7Li and 13C nuclei, respectively. For comparison, 13C MAS NMR measurement of the VEC monomer was performed on the same spectrometer at a static state. Ionic conductivity of the PVEC-PE was by tested EIS using Versa STAT 3 system at varied temperatures ranging from −15 to 55 °C. The bulk resistance (R b) of PE was determined from the impedance spectrum that sandwiched between two stainless-steel (SS) plate electrodes and the spectra were recorded in the frequency range of 0.1–106 Hz with an AC amplitude of 10 mV. The ionic conductivity was calculated from equation:σ =
L
R b
S
, where R b is the bulk resistance, L and S are the thickness and area of the PVEC-PE, respectively. The electrochemical stability window was investigated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) performed on a working electrode of SS, Li metal as the counter and reference electrode of PVEC-PE at a scan rate of 1.0 mV s−1 between 2 and 5.5 V. The lithium-ion transference number (tLi +) was calculated by the chronoamperometry test on the Li/PVEC/Li symmetry battery with an applied voltage of 0.01 V and was determined by following equation:
t Li +

I ss

I ss
R ss
, where I0 and Iss are the initial and steady-state currents, and R0 and Rss are the first and last resistances, respectively. The tests were completed by EIS measurements taken before and after the polarization scans over a frequency range of 0.1–106 Hz with a 10 mV amplitude at 25 °C. To examine the cathodes after battery measurements, the solid polymer batteries were firstly disassembled in an Ar filled glove box. The cathodes were collected after removing the PE film.

The LiFePO4 (LFP) or LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCA) cathode was composed of 80 wt% LFP/NCA, 15 wt% carbon black, 5 wt% binder (PVDF: EVC-LiTFSI = 7:3). The solid battery based on different cathode with areal density of ~3.0–5.0 mg cm−2 has been explored. The solid polymer lithium metal batteries composed of both LiFePO4 and LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathodes that assembled by the in-situ or ex-situ process were charged and discharged between 2.5 and 4.0 V at varied current densities. The C rates in all the electrochemical measurements are defined based on 1C = 170 mA g−1 for LFP and 1C = 200 mA g−1 for NCA. The battery was assembled in an argon-filled glove box, with oxygen content less than 5 ppm and H2O content less than 1 ppm. The galvanostatic charge/discharge tests of CR2032 were conducted on LAND testing system (Wuhan LAND electronics Co., Ltd.) at 25 °C.

The PVEC-PE has been fabricated by a solution casting method (See the experimental section). Simply, the VEC monomer, Li salt and catalyst were added into a glass bottle simultaneously and stirred intensely to form a homogeneous solution. After that, the solution was poured into the filter paper on the poly-tetra fluoroethylene (PTFE) plate and then dried for polymerization with 12 h. Then the free-standing PVEC-PE with good flexibility can be obtained. For the characterizations and battery tests, the PVEC-PE film has been prepared through the polymerization of precursor in the coin cell and obtained after disassembling. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the VEC monomer has the CC bond (the red area), which can be polymerized into a chain structure of PVEC, without any change of the CO bond and five-membered ring structure. The polymerization mechanism of PVEC-PE has further been verified by Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) and Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR). As can be seen from NMR (Fig. 1b), there was no obvious signal of CC in PE after the polymerization reaction with the fixed amount of catalyst and time. A new broad peak can be observed, corresponding to the C–C bond after the polymerization of CC bond in PVEC-PE. Meanwhile, the broad peaks without position shift of the five-membered ring structure have further confirmed the formation mechanism for the polymerization of liquid precursor. From FT-IR in Fig. 1c, the typical absorption peak of CC bond in VEC monomer at 1640 cm−1 disappeared, following by the formation of a new bending vibration peak of -(C–C)n-bond at 720 cm−1, which indicates the polymerization from VEC monomer into PVEC-PE. Meanwhile, there was no obvious shift of peak position of CO bond (1740 cm−1) and C–O bond (1054 cm−1), indicating the stability of CO and C–O bond before and after the polymerization, which is beneficial for the Li+ transports.

From the detection of X-ray diffraction (XRD) of PVEC-PE in Fig. 1d, it can be found that some weak peaks in the pattern of PE, which should be ascribed to the low crystallinity of PVEC-PE, and could be beneficial for enhancing the Li+ transports. From the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image of the top surface of PVEC-PE (Fig. S1a), it can be found that the surface of PVEC-PE is smooth and homogenous, which is beneficial for making the favorable contact to the electrodes. From the cross-sectional image of PVEC-PE in Fig. S1b, a dense structure of PE has been achieved, which can effectively prevent the possible inner short-circuit and improve the safety and reliability of LMBs. Furthermore, the large size PVEC-PE with homogenous structure after polymerization has an excellent mechanical property (Insert in Fig. 1d), and good flexibility with variable shape (Fig. S1c), which are in favor for the strong adhesion to the electrodes and making the batteries with tunable size and architecture.

The ionic conductivity (σ) of PVEC-PE has been evaluated at different temperatures ranging from −15 to 55 °C (Fig. 2 a and Fig. S2a), and the results have been calculated by the bulk resistance (R b) of PE film from the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) of SS/PVEC-PE/SS (SS: stainless steel) symmetrical battery. From Fig. 2a, it can be found that the ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE increase simultaneously with the increase of temperature. The ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE can be up to ~2.1 mS cm−1 at 25 °C. More importantly, the ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE can still keep at 1.1 mS cm−1 at low temperature of 5 °C and 0.4 mS cm−1 at −15 °C respectively, which can ensure normal work of LMBs in a wide temperature range. The temperature-dependent ionic conductivity behavior of PVEC-PE can be fitted by the Arrhenius plots as Equation
σ = A
T
1 / 2
exp
[
−
E a
R
(
T −
T o
)
]
, where A is the pre-exponential factor, Ea is the activation energy, and T is the absolute temperature, To is the Vogel scaling temperature at which the free volume disappears or at which configuration free entropy becomes zero (To = 236/K), and R is the ideal gas constant [40]. Thus, the low activation energy (0.159 eV) indicates the low energy barrier for Li+ transport in PVEC-PE. Furthermore, the PVEC-PE has the highest the ionic conductivities when compared to that of reported PEs [27,40,44,52,53] (Fig. 2b). Besides the superior ionic conductivity, the PVEC-PE has a high structure stability (Fig. S2b), which are beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical performances of LMBs significantly.

The electrochemical stability window of PE is critical for the practical application in LMBs. From a linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) of an asymmetrical cell of Li/PVEC-PE/SS at 25 °C (Fig. 2c), it can be seen that there is no obvious oxidation current before 4.5 V (vs. Li+/Li) which is favorable for the practical applications of PVEC-PE for high-potential cathode material in solid polymer LMBs. In addition to chemical stability, the electrochemical stability of PVEC-PE with Li metal anode has also been explored by the Cyclic Voltammograms (CV) of the Li/PVEC-PE/SS battery in a voltage range of −0.5 to 1.6 V (insert in Fig. 2c). As can be seen, there were only reversible lithium plating/stripping peaks in different scan cycles, which revealed the electrochemically interfacial stability toward Li metal anode. The Li+ transference number (tLi +) is the ratio of Li+ transport to the total ions (cations and anions) that transport in the electrolyte, which is an important parameter for evaluating the PEs [54]. The low tLi + leads to the maldistribution of ionic concentration, side reactions and polarization of electrodes. From the direct current polarization and EIS tests in Fig. 2d, the tLi + of PVEC-PE is ~0.40 at 25 °C, which is higher than the liquid electrolyte [55]. The high tLi + of PVEC-PE should be mainly due to the strong electron withdrawing capability of CO groups and limitation of anoins (TFSI−) movement, which is beneficial for increasing the tLi + of PVEC-PE and therefore, reducing concentration polarization and improving rate performance of batteries [40,56]. Followed by this polarization test, the interfacial compatibility between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode has also been explored (inset in Fig. 2d). From the EIS of the symmetrical cell before and after polarization, there is no obvious change of R b and interfacial resistance (R i), indicating the stable interface contact between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode. Thermal gravimetric (TG) analysis of VEC and PVEC-PE (Fig. 2e) has demonstrated the thermal stability of PVEC-PE, which could be utilized at elevated temperatures up to 130 °C. Therefore, the safety of LMBs can be significantly improved by the excellent mechanical property and thermal stability of PVEC-PE.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Mechanism of Li+ transports in PVEC-PE
ce:section.ce:para: The origin of superior ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE has been systematically explored by multiple characterizations. For one thing, the polymerization process of PVEC-PE has been explored by evaluating the σ depending on the amount of catalyst. By varying the mass fraction of catalyst from 0.1 to 5% 25 °C (Fig. 3 a), it can be found that the σ of PVEC-PE can be up to ~6.3 × 10−3 S cm−1 (6.3 mS cm−1) when the low mass fraction of catalyst of 0.1 wt%, which was much closer to that of liquid electrolyte, indicating the high amount of low molecular polymer of PVEC-PE, which will be discussed later. However, the mechanical property of PVEC-PE is very low and not easy to be handled for the test. There was a rapid decrease of σ with increasing the mass fraction of catalyst from 0.1 to 0.5 wt%, indicating the decrease of low molecular polymer in the PE. Furthermore, the σ can be still kept at ~2.1 mS cm−1 when the mass fraction of catalyst greater than 0.5 wt%, and there was no obvious change of σ even the amount of catalyst up to be 5 wt%, which demonstrates the sufficient polymerization of PVEC-PE. Thus, the AIBN catalyst with the amount of 1 wt% has been applied for the preparation of PVEC-PE for the characterizations and solid batteries.

Besides, the relationship between the σ and polymerization time has also been explored. With the fixed amount of catalyst, it can be found that the σ decreased with the increase of polymerization time. After 10 h, there is no change of the σ, which shows the sufficient polymerization of PVEC-PE. Therefore, the 12 h was selected for the polymerization of PVEC-PE in our work (Fig. S3). For another, the molecular weight and proportion of different molecular polymer in the PVEC-PE with different mass fraction of catalyst have been obtained by the Gel Permeation Chromatography (GPC) tests, which can be used for the calculation of polymerization degree (nw) [44] (Fig. 3b). It can be found that there are two different peaks of GPC results, in which the peak1 and peak2 were corresponding to the high molecular polymer and low molecular polymer in the PVEC-PE respectively. With the low amount of catalyst with 0.1 wt%, there is a high proportion of low molecular polymer in the PVEC-PE, resulting the high σ by facilitating the fast Li+ transports. Combining with the insert in Fig. 3b and Table S1, the proportion of low molecular polymer has decreased with the increase of mass fraction of catalyst, in which the σ of PVEC-PE decreased simultaneously. However, the nw1 for high molecular polymer is much higher than nw2 for low molecular polymer, and meanwhile, the proportion of high molecular polymer have increased with increasing the mass fraction of catalyst. More importantly, there was no liquid precursor in the PVEC-PE, no matter the mass fraction of catalyst is low or high, which is consistent with the NMR and FT-IR results in Fig. 1b and c. Therefore, the interior structure schematic of the PVEC-PE that composed of high molecular and low molecular polymers, Li+ and anion can be obtained. As shown in Fig. 3c, with the high proportion (>90%) of high molecular polymers as the backbone, the PVEC-PE displays a superior ionic conductivity by offer sufficient Li+ pathway for facilitating fast Li+ transports, outstanding mechanical strength and thermal stability for assembling the polymer LMBs. Furthermore, small amount of low molecular polymer may filled in the space of high molecular polymer backbone, which was beneficial for enhancing the ions transports, lowering the crystallinity of PE, reducing interfacial resistance and improving interfacial compatibility between PVEC-PE and electrodes.

In order to detect the interior mechanism of Li+ transport pathways in PVEC-PE, the interactions between Li+ and CO/C–O groups have also been investigated by theoretical simulations (Fig. 3d). From the atomic valence state (AVS) of the unit in PVEC-PE that calculated by Bader, it can be seen that the AVS of oxygen atom in C–O was −0.99, which was slightly higher than that of oxygen atom in CO (−1.04), indicating that the Li+ tend to interact with CO groups compared to C–O groups. Furthermore, the steric hindrance effect can also weaken the interaction between Li+ and C–O groups. Thus, both of the CO and C–O groups can interact with Li+, in which the former interaction is stronger than that of the later [36]. Besides the theoretical simulations, the interactions between Li+ and functional group were studied by 7Li and 6Li NMR spectra, which have been analyzed after different cycle time in Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetric battery. From 7Li NMR spectra in Fig. 3e, only one peak (−0.2 ppm) can be observed after different cycle time, indicating the interaction between Li+ and CO groups in the process of Li+ transports [57]. In addition, the increase of peak width with increasing the cycle time should be attributed to structural heterogeneity that caused by interactions between the non-homogeneous Li+ and CO groups in polymer after long cycles as well as the exchange between nearby Li+. Quadrupolar 6Li nuclei is more sensitive to the local chemical environment than 7Li, which could provide further details. Similar to 7Li NMR spectra, the 6Li NMR spectra have also revealed the strong interaction between Li+ and CO groups in the process of Li+ migrations (peak of −0.2 ppm in Fig. 3f). Moreover, a weak peak at −0.8 ppm was probed in 6Li NMR spectra, corresponding to interactions between Li+ and C–O groups [58]. With long cycle time, besides the increase of interaction between Li+ and CO groups, the intensity of the signal at −0.8 ppm has also increased, indicating more Li+ ions interact with C–O groups in the process of Li+ migrations. These observations confirmed the dominant Li+ transport paths through the interactions between Li+ and CO in PVEC-PE at the first few cycles, while more Li+ interacted with C–O groups after more cycles. Similarly, the broaden peak width should attribute to structural heterogeneity that caused by Li+ dispersions after interacting with CO and C–O groups, and probably the moving/exchange of Li+ between CO and C–O groups. As shown in Fig. 3g, it can be concluded that the superior ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE should be mainly originated from the fast Li+ transports through the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms of CO groups (Path 1) during the process of segmental motion of high and low molecular polymers. Then, Li+ transports can also be partially achieved through the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms of C–O groups (Path 2). Meanwhile the moving/exchange of Li+ between CO and C–O groups (Path 3) has probably existed as probed by the NMR results. The mixed ions transport mechanism should be originated from the unique structure of PVEC-PE, in which the five-membered ring containing CO and C–O bonds can rotate around the polymerized C–C bond (red in Fig. S4a) that connect with the main chains, resulting in the relative location change of neighbouring five-membered ring. Although the poly(vinyl carbonate) (PVCA) polymer electrolyte with similar five-membered ring structure has been proposed for the polymer LMBs (Fig. S4b) [40], it is still suffered by the low ionic conductivity of 2.23 × 10−5 S cm−1 at 25 °C, which should be caused by the fixed location of five-membered ring in PVCA-PE that generated via a polymerization of CC bond in the ring structure, and may not be favorable for the fast ions transports. Furthermore, the small amount of low molecular polymer can reduce the crystallinity and facile internal rotation of PVEC-PE, which are in favor for enhancing the ions transports in the PE, and prominently reducing the activation energies for ions transports [59].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Interfacial compatibility between PVEC-PE and electrode
ce:section.ce:para: It has been demonstrated that the interfacial resistance in the solid-state battery can be reduced via in-situ polymerization of PE (in-situ PVEC-PE) [44]. Herein, the interfacial contact between PVEC-PE and electrode has also been enhanced by in-situ polymerization process. From the cross-sectional SEM image of the Li/in-situ PVEC-PE in Fig. 4 a, the good interface compatibility with excellent adhesion between PE and Li metal anode can be achieved by in-situ polymerization process. However, there was an obvious gap between Li/PVEC-PE (Fig. 4b) by conventional/ex-situ method (ex-situ PVEC-PE). Herein, for the consistency, the ex-situ PVEC-PE is fabricated through the polymerization of precursor in the coin cell, and then obtained after disassembling. Furthermore, the interfacial contact and stability between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode has been investigated by polarization test of the symmetric battery with the current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 for 1 h (Fig. 4c). The two batteries with in-situ and ex-situ PVEC-PE can work for over 600 h without short circuiting, indicating the reversible cycling stability for lithium plating/stripping in PVEC-PE based LMBs. Moreover, the Li/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery maintains an extremely low voltage polarization with over-potential slightly increases from 30 mV at initial to 50 mV after 600 h for lithium plating/stripping at the current density of 0.1 mA cm−2, which was much lower than that of Li/ex-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery. The low polarization of Li plating/stripping should be attributed to the significant improvement of interfacial compatibility between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode that achieved by in-situ polymerization method. Moreover, at various current densities, there is no short circuit for the Li/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery (Fig. S5a). Therefore, the favorable interface compatibility and stability with low interfacial resistance between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode via in-situ polymerization process are beneficial for enhancing the electrochemical performances of polymer LMBs. In addition, the R i of Li/PVEC-PE/Li symmetrical cell that fabricated by in-situ polymerization process and conventional method has been compared. It can be found that the R i of Li/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li cell (~70 Ω) is much smaller than that of Li/ex-situ PVEC-PE/Li (~225 Ω) (Fig. 4d), which further confirms the significant enhancement of interfacial compatibility between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode that achieved via in-situ polymerization process. In addition, after long aging time, there was no obvious change of R b (Fig. S5b), similar to that of the tendency in the SS/PVEC-PE/SS symmetric battery (Fig. S2b), indicating the stability of PVEC-PE over long time [60]. More importantly, the R i of the Li/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li cell increases slightly from ~70 Ω at initial state to ~88 Ω after interior stabilization for 14 days (Fig. S5b). After that, there was no obvious change of R i with aging time from 10 to 28 days, demonstrating a stable interface contact between PVEC-PE and Li metal anode. Therefore, an outstanding structure stability and excellent interface compatibility toward Li metal anode can be achieved via in-situ polymerization of PVEC-PE, which can improve the electrochemical performances of polymer LMBs.

Similarly, it can be expected that the interfacial contact between PVEC-PE and cathode can also be enhanced greatly by in-situ polymerization process (Figs. S6a and b). For the composite cathode membrane composed of porous LiFePO4 cathode layer and ex-situ PVEC-PE film, there are an obvious delamination with the interface between two composites, in which the interface contact was not intimate. Thus, after tens of cycles, there were still plenty of pores in the cathode layer, in which the pathways were not sufficient for Li+ diffusions among the active materials, resulting the poor electrochemical performances (Insert in Fig. 4e and Fig. S6c). On the contrary, for the composite cathode membrane combined with in-situ PVEC-PE film, the pores inside the cathode layer are filled by the PE, in which a good wetting ability of liquid polymer precursor into the cathode layer (Insert in Fig. 4e and Fig. S6d). From the mass ratios (Fig. 4e) and EDS mapping of C, O and F elements (Figs. S6e and f), they have further demonstrated the good interface compatibility between in-situ PVEC-PE film and cathode layer. Therefore, the intimate contact between LiFePO4 cathode and PVEC-PE via in-situ polymerization process can effectively reduce the interfacial resistance, and greatly enhance the Li+ transport as well as the electrochemical performances of polymer LMBs.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Electrochemical performances of PVEC-PE based LMBs
ce:section.ce:para: As discussed above, the interfacial contact can be enhanced greatly by in-situ polymerization of PVEC-PE. Therefore, the LiFePO4/PVEC-PE/Li battery have been assembled in one step via in-situ polymerization method. For comparisons, the solid battery has also been assembled by the traditional method, in which the PVEC-PE film was adopted and obtained by disassembling the coin cell after polymerization. Fig. 5 a shows the initial charge-discharge curves of LiFePO4/PVEC-PE/Li batteries assembled via in-situ and ex-situ method at the current density of 0.1C (1C = 170 mA g−1). It can be seen that the initial discharge capacity of in-situ PVEC-PE based battery is ~165 mA h g−1, which is larger than ~150 mA h g−1 of ex-situ battery. Besides, the over-potential between stable charge/discharge potentials of in-situ battery is much smaller than that of ex-situ battery, which has been further proved by the CV in Fig. S7a. The cycling stabilities of two different batteries are also compared (Fig. 5b), in which the in-situ PVEC-PE based battery shows a discharge capacity of ~140 mA h g−1 from the initial cycle and keeps stability over 100 cycles with the coulombic efficiency of ~99% (Fig. S7b) at the current density of 1C. Even more, the battery can keep the reversible specific capacity of ~118 mA h g−1 for 100 cycles at high current density of 3C (Fig. S7c), which should be originated from the improved interfacial contact between PVEC-PE and the electrodes. Fig. 5c displays the rate performances of LMBs with the current densities increase from 0.1C to 2C. The in-situ PVEC-PE based battery exhibits the specific capacity of ~158 mA h g−1 at 0.2C, and ~113 mA h g−1 at 2C, which are much larger than that of ex-situ PVEC-PE based battery with the specific capacity from ~140 mA h g−1 to ~40 mA h g−1 at the corresponding current densities. Furthermore, the over-potentials increase and the capacity decreases continuously with the increase of current densities, which should be caused by the polarization effect (Fig. S7d). The interfacial resistances of the LiFePO4/PVEC-PE/Li batteries before and after 100 cycles has been explored by the EIS (Fig. S7e). The interfacial resistances of in-situ battery (~220 Ω at initial state and ~300 Ω after 100 cycles) are much smaller than that of ex-situ battery (~499 Ω and ~1106 Ω), which have further confirmed the excellent and stable interface contact and been consisting with the good rate performances and long cycling stability (Fig. 5b and c). As the ionic conductivity of PVEC-PE is still high at low temperature, the LiFePO4/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery still deliver the high discharge capacity of ~146 mA h g−1 at 5 °C, ~136 mA h g−1 at −5 °C, and even ~104 mA h g−1 at −15 °C at the current density of 0.1C (Fig. 5d). Even more, the specific capacity can be still up to ~106 mA h g−1, ~90 mA h g−1 and ~64 mA h g−1 at three different temperatures under high current density of 1C (Fig. S7f), indicating the possible application of PVEC-PE for LMBs at low temperature. The solid LMBs based on LiFePO4 cathode with high loading amount of ~5 mg cm−2 can also show the high discharge capacities and good rate performances (Fig. S7g). Besides LiFePO4 cathode, this PVEC-PE can also be applied in the high potential LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 (NCA) cathode material. Via the same in-situ polymerization process for the assembling, the NCA/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery has showed a high initial discharge capacity of ~190 mA h g−1 with the coulombic efficiency of ~85.6% at the current density of 0.1C (1C = 200 mA g−1) (Fig. 5e), and the outstanding cycling stability with the discharge capacity of ~110 mA h g−1 after 200 charge/discharge cycles at the current density of 1C (Fig. 5f and Fig. S8a). Furthermore, the batteries display the favorable rate performances at variable current densities, and the specific capacity still maintains ~106 mA h g−1 at 3C (Figs. S8b and c). Therefore, with the superior ionic conductivity and excellent interface compatibility between PE and electrodes, this PVEC-PE is a promising candidate for the high-energy polymer LMBs with outstanding rate performances and good cycling stabilities.

The soft-package LiFePO4/in-situ PVEC-PE/Li battery has been assembled for exploring the practical applications in electrical devices (Fig. 5g). It can be found the battery can light up the logo “BJUT” that composed of nearly 70 light-emitting diode (LED) lamps successfully. Even more, the soft-package battery can still be able to light up the logo when it is cut, bended and wrinkled, indicating no short-circuit of the battery during the shape change. Therefore, with high safety and reliability of our flexible PVEC-PE, it can be applied in the wearable devices that desired for high energy density.

In summary, we have developed a novel PVEC-PE for the polymer LMBs. The superior ionic conductivity of ~2.1 mS cm−1 at 25 °C and stable potential window up to 4.5 V (vs. Li+/Li) have been achieved. The superior ionic conductivity is mainly attributed to the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in CO groups, partially from the coupling/decoupling between Li+ and oxygen atoms in C–O groups, and probably moving/exchange of Li+ between CO and C–O groups in the process of segmental motion of high and low molecular polymers in PVEC-PE. Moreover, the excellent interface compatibility between electrodes with PEs can be obtained via in-situ polymerization method. The polymer LMBs composed of LiFePO4 or LiNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 cathode that assembled by in-situ polymerization of polymer electrolyte can deliver highly reversible specific capacities, excellent cycling stabilities and outstanding rate performances at 25 °C. Furthermore, the soft-package batteries based on PVEC-PE deliver high safety and reliability for lighting up a group of LED lamps. Therefore, the PVEC-PE designed in this work is one of the most promising candidates for the practical applications of polymer LMBs and has potential applications in the flexible electrical devices with high energy density.
